qas.question: What is a complication of chronic asthma?
If you are 65 years old and have an obstructive airway disesase, you are more likely to have what other conditions?

answers.text: by increased airway neutrophils, abnormally increased wall thickness, and increased smooth muscle in the bronchi

qas.question: Why is this not determined in a patient with COPD?

answers.text: due to COPD and asthma sharing similar principles of management

qas.question: What are the principles of management for asthma and COPD?

answers.text: corticosteroids, long acting beta agonists, and smoking cessation

qas.question: What is a complication of family history of chronic atopy?
If you smoke after 65, what two conditions will you also have?

plausible_answers.text: increased airway neutrophils, abnormally increased wall thickness, and increased smooth muscle in the bronchi

qas.question: How can you tell who has stopped smoking and who hasn't?

plausible_answers.text: corticosteroids, long acting beta agonists, and smoking cessation

qas.question: What principles of management are used for increased airway neutrophils and smoking cessation?

plausible_answers.text: more exposure to cigarette smoke, an older age

qas.question: What are two things that make a doctor want to investigate family history of atopy?

context: <a0_0><b5_0>Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease<b5_0/><a0_0/> can coexist with asthma and can occur as a complication of chronic asthma. After the age of 65 most people with obstructive airway disease will have <a1_0><b6_0>asthma and COPD<b6_0/><a1_0/>. In this setting, COPD can be differentiated <a2_0>by <b7_0>increased airway neutrophils, abnormally increased wall thickness, and increased smooth muscle in the bronchi<b7_0/><a2_0/>. However, this level of investigation is not performed <a3_0>due to COPD and asthma sharing similar principles of management<a3_0/>: <a4_0><b8_0>corticosteroids, long acting beta agonists, and smoking cessation<b8_0/><a4_0/>. It closely resembles asthma in symptoms, is correlated with <b9_0>more exposure to cigarette smoke, an older age<b9_0/>, less symptom reversibility after bronchodilator administration, and decreased likelihood of family history of atopy.
